bullets.text: Trump’s Greenland push strains U.S.-Europe/NATO ties, raising risk of retaliatory tariffs and broader transatlantic trade conflict.
Europe weighs deploying its trade “bazooka” against the U.S.; targeted exporters and autos flagged as highly exposed to potential Greenland-linked tariffs.
Markets react to Greenland/EU tensions: U.S. stock futures dip, auto shares fall, and gold/silver hit fresh highs on safe-haven demand.
Supreme Court fight over removing Fed Governor Lisa Cook tests central-bank independence; Powell attending underscores institutional stakes for policy credibility.
Trump’s trade team signals immediate response to tariff-related court setbacks, increasing policy volatility risk for cross-border supply chains and inflation expectations.
China’s growth slows (Q4 ~4.5%); Beijing keeps benchmark lending rates unchanged despite weaker consumption, reinforcing concerns over demand and policy constraints.
China’s equities show overheating signs (record turnover); regulators grow wary, highlighting financial-stability risks amid slowing real-economy momentum.
China’s birthrate hits a record low, deepening long-run aging pressures on labor supply, productivity, pensions, and potential growth.
Japan 40-year government bond yields reach fresh highs, signaling tighter long-end conditions and global duration sensitivity amid geopolitical trade shocks.
Private credit funds keep raising billions despite warnings, suggesting investors are accepting liquidity/credit risks to replace shrinking bank balance-sheet lending.
Venezuela illustrates “dollarization via stablecoins”: locals increasingly use USDT as state capacity weakens, shifting payments and savings outside domestic institutions.
Battery/materials advances: silver-enabled solid-state improvements could accelerate higher-energy, safer storage—key to EVs and grid reliability competition.
NOAA reports severe geomagnetic-storm conditions; elevated solar activity raises near-term risks to satellites, aviation, GPS, and power-grid operations.
Major review finds no autism/ADHD risk from prenatal Tylenol, reducing perceived litigation/regulatory pressure and clarifying guidance for maternal healthcare decisions.
